DOC.HEAD: Uganda Says Sudanese Attacked Border Town
DOC.TEXT: State-controlled Radio Uganda claimed Saturday that Sudanese troops attacked a small Ugandan military post at the border town of Oraba, killing one soldier. The broadcast quoted a Ministry of Defense statement as saying the Sudanese army troops struck the border post Friday morning and were still in Ugandan territory at nightfall. The report said the Sudanese troops were traveling in 16 trucks and supported by an armored personnel carrier and artillery. It said the small border post detachment withdrew after one of its members was killed in the attack. The Sudanese force then moved farther into Ugandan territory, it added. The report could not be independently verified. Sudanese Embassy officials in Kampala refused to comment on the report. Sudan's army has been fighting an insurgency in the southern half of the country for nearly seven years, and the rebels often cross into Uganda for sanctuary. The Ugandan military high command has accused the Khartoum government of ``aiding and abetting'' Ugandan guerrillas who operate along the border. In October, Uganda claimed several Sudanese warplanes bombed another border town, Moyo, killing several civilians.
